title: Fire spinning: a flammable mix of dance, martial arts, extreme sport and meditation - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Mr Schmerl has just returned from a teaching tour in the United States where he said Australian fire spinners were "very well respected". 
"The number of Australians pushing technical boundaries, and our technical skills, is world class." Remaining focussed between the flames 
Spinning objects while weaving and contorting your body around the flames is both mentally and physically demanding. 
"You definitely need to be fit, but [fire spinning] helps you along with that," Mr Schmerl said. 
"I've done a solo show of more than half an hour and they are very draining. 
"I walk away from those with nothing [left]." ABC Adelaide: Brett Williamson 
Mr Schmerl said fire spinning was also commonly used as a mediation technique. 
"There's no time to let your mind run away with thought as you have to be very present with what you are doing," he said. 
"You have to have a defined focus for a long time. 
Any lapse in concentration and hairs could be singed â€” something Mr Schmerl has experienced with his beard, which would otherwise be a lot longer. 
"When I do decide to go a little more risky, I accept that I might get burned. 
"They usually hurt for a couple of days in the shower." 
Mr Schmerl said fire spinning had become a lifetime pursuit and he has planned tours to Indonesia, America and Europe. 
"I'm not sure if I will chase it like a career and go into circuses, but who knows?" he said. Share
